                Getty

                        Conservatives and Democrats are equally sure they benefit from a fight that threatens to shut down the government.

            By 
Lauren French
             and 
Jennifer Haberkorn

09/09/15, 06:22 PM EDT
Congress is about to find out what happens when an unstoppable force meets an immovable object.
Both Democrats and conservative Republicans are vowing not to budge from their entrenched positions on Planned Parenthood funding even at the risk of a government shutdown on Oct. 1 – creating a political showdown between the two parties that deeply appeals to their base and promises to make life miserable for Speaker John Boehner. 
Each side is equally convinced the fight only benefits them politically – and that they have every incentive to dig in and nothing to gain from compromise.
Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi said Wednesday that Democrats won't support any funding measure that attacks Planned Parenthood. She argued that Republicans are only damaging their party among women. And she’s in a strong position: Boehner has been forced to routinely turn to Democrats in the House on must-pass legislation and Democratic leaders are confident the Ohio Republican will work with them again.



            By 
Burgess Everett

But Boehner’s other adversaries – a cadre of hardline conservatives – are just as determined to strip Planned Parenthood of the $540 million it receives in government funding. More than 30 lawmakers have signed on to a letter from South Carolina Rep. Mick Mulvaney pledging to not vote for any funding measure that appropriates money to the health care organization.
And the roughly 35 members of the House Freedom Caucus are expected to take a similar stand this week, lawmakers have said.
“I think leadership is going to have to choose, do they want it to be a talking point or do they actually want to do something about it,” Mulvaney said.
The contentious issue has dominated lawmakers’ attention after nine videos were released over the summer allegedly depicting agents of Planned Parenthood discussing fetal tissue sales. The group denies any wrongdoing.
Democrats say the Republican effort only validates their long-running argument that Republicans are waging a “war on women.”
“How dare they be so disrespectful to women. How dare they be so disregarding of women's health issues. Since I have been here - it's 28 years - they have been out to get Planned Parenthood,” Pelosi (D-Calif.) said.
She suggested that the anti-Planned Parenthood push could will come back to haunt the GOP in next year's general election.
“This budget," Pelosi said, "is a lot bigger than the ideology….of a few in that caucus.”
But Republicans are also certain they've got a winner. GOP voters are staunchly opposed to abortion and the conservative lawmakers view fighting Planned Parenthood funding as fulfilling their campaign promises. Rep. Raul Labrador of Idaho, one of the Freedom Caucus’ leaders, said that while conservatives are not advocating for a shutdown, his fellow right-wingers “can’t be afraid of having the battle.”
“If you telegraph to the other side that you’re unwilling to have that battle you’ve already capitulated. What you say is you’re going to use all the tools available,” he said.
The ingrained positions have the makings of a dramatic three weeks in Congress. Lawmakers have to pass a budget bill, or continuing resolution, to fund the government before Oct. 1. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has already said his chamber doesn’t have the votes to defund Planned Parenthood and House GOP leaders have yet to formalize a plan to move forward.



            By 
Jake Sherman

Boehner told Republicans during a closed-door conference Wednesday that allowing a government shutdown over Planned Parenthood could hurt the cause of lawmakers who oppose abortion rights. The House is expected to hold a government funding vote next week but are still split on how to tackle funding for the group. The conservatives are meeting with House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.), Majority Whip Steve Scalise (R-La.) and Republican Conference Chairman Cathy McMorris Rogers (R-Wash.) to chart a course forward.
Democrats want to keep the debate focused on abortion and preserving the constitutional right of a woman to obtain the procedure until a fetus is viable instead of having to talk about the gruesome images captured in the sting videos.
At a House Judiciary Committee hearing Wednesday, Democrats blasted Republicans for trying to use the video controversy to try to overturn Roe v. Wade. Republicans “won’t be happy until abortion is outlawed in the United States of America,” said Rep. Steve Cohen (D-Tenn.).
They’re also trying to refocus the conversation away from Planned Parenthood and on to the group that made the surreptitious videos, the Center for Medical Progress, and its founder, David Daleiden. Planned Parenthood and its allies allege that the group has ties to violent anti-abortion activists, which its executives strongly deny. Democrats also allege that the group violated state and federal laws in the course of obtaining the undercover video and interviews.
“Republicans are frothing at the mouth at Planned Parenthood….,” Rep. Steve Israel (D-N.Y.) said. “House Democrats will use every opportunity this month to highlight the GOP's 'déjà vu all over again' strategy and misplaced priorities.”
Conservatives, however, see this as the best chance they’ve had in decades to seriously curb Planned Parenthood’s funding – and create a discussion about Republican priorities in Congress. Ohio Rep. Jim Jordan, the chairman of the conservative Freedom Caucus, said Republicans aren't afraid to discuss the problems they see within Planned Parenthood in their effort to defund the group.
They’ve floated an alternative measure that would redirect the government funding Planned Parenthood receives to health care clinics.
“The dollar amount will be exactly the same…it will go to other organizations that are not involved with what looks like criminal activity,” Jordan said. “But the reality is to just have a show vote [isn’t enough]… What they did is immoral.”

                                            By 
John Culhane


                                            By 
Sue Bell Cobb


                                            By 
Mark Perry


                                            By 
Alan Wolfe

description: Conservatives and Democrats are equally sure they benefit from a fight that threatens to shut down the government.
title: On Planned Parenthood, both sides see a winner
